Award.AwardTitle: Semiclassical Analysis in Inverse Problems; on Kac's problem and Calderon's problem
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is concerned with applications of semiclassical analysis in studying the behavior of the solutions of partial differential equations in terms of the geometry of their underlying spaces. Semiclassical analysis studies the transition between quantum and classical mechanics. A unifying idea in this area is to study the behavior of quantum mechanical objects such as eigenvalues (energy levels) and eigenfunctions (quantum states) in terms of classical objects like the geodesic flow. The Principal Investigator studies Kac's well-known inverse spectral problem for analytic domains by introducing new tools. In particular, the project will investigate explicit formulas for the complicated wave invariants in order to improve existing results on this subject. The Principal Investigator will also pursue applications of semiclassical analysis to another celebrated problem, Calderon's inverse problem with partial data.

The Principal Investigator works in the field of partial differential equations. His project focuses on two very important inverse problems in mathematics and physics, namely, Kac's inverse problem and Calderon's inverse problem. Kac's inverse problem asks roughly whether one can determine the shapes of objects (such as stars) from the wave frequencies that they emit. The Principal Investigator approaches this problem by developing new computational tools that lead to an improved understanding of the relationship between the waves and the shapes of the objects. Such inverse spectral problems, as some engineers have recently suggested, may also have interesting applications in shape-matching, copyright, and medical imaging analysis. The Calderon inverse problem (or, in its technical formulation, the problem of electric impedance tomography) asks whether one can determine the conductivity of a body on the basis of current and voltage measurements taken at its surface. This inverse method has been proposed as a valuable diagnostic tool in medicine for the early detection of breast cancer. The past ten years have seen considerable developments in this area, but the problem with partial data (meaning for measurements taken only on pieces of the surface) remains an open problem. The project investigates the partial data problem with the aid of new analytical techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My proposal concerned the interplay between Newtonian mechanics and quantum mechanics. Semiclassical analysis is a field in mathematics that studies such relations. The main theme in this field is that the behavior of quantum mechanical objects such as energies and wave functions of quantum objects can be studied using the dynamical system and the geometry of the underlying space.  My proposal concentrated mainly on two major topics in semiclassical analysis:

(1) Inverse spectral problems: ``Can one hear the shape of a drum?’’ The famous inverse problem of Kac is to determine the shape of an (arbitrary shaped) drum from the spectrum (the frequencies of vibration) of the drum. The physical motivation is to identify remote physical objects such as stars or atoms from the light or sound they emit. This problem was phrased by Kac as ``can one hear the shape of a drum?’’ The answer to Kac’s problem is negative, meaning there exist two non-isometric domains in the plane with the same spectrum. But what if we require some natural conditions on our drum or object, such as smoothness or symmetries? There has been an enormous amount of research on this topic, but there are still many open problems left. As a result of this proposal, I proved some new inverse problems (in a joint work with S. Zelditch) for drums that are of the shape of an ellipse. We showed that roughly speaking such drums can be heard among smooth drums with two mirror symmetries. Also in joint works with K. Datchev and I. Ventura, I proved inverse spectral results for Schrodinger operators with radial potentials.  In a work with V. Guillemin, we studied the obstructions and limitations of common methods, namely trace formulas, in studying inverse spectral problems.

(2) Zeros (nodal set) of eigenfunctions. Eigenfunctions arise in physics as modes of periodic vibration of drums and membranes. The eigenfunctions of Schrodinger operators represent stationary energy states of atoms and molecules in quantum mechanics. Zeros of eigenfunctions represent places that the particle is less likely to hang out. The patterns of nodal lines (zeros) attracted physicists and mathematicians since the famous experiment of Chladni. An interesting subject is studying the behavior of the nodal sets when the frequency of the wave function is very high, because that is when interesting patterns form and the underlying classical system starts to show itself.  A basic question is the size of nodal sets. Donnelly and Fefferman proved that the total size of the nodal sets of a Laplace eigenfunction with energy E on real analytic manifolds is of order square root of E. This problem still remains open for non-analytic Riemannian manifolds. In joint works with Z. Wang and C. Sogge, I found new estimates for the size of nodal sets in the non-analytic setting.
